Core:PCProperties.Core:Property:
(\{ (\{ "+\\
The Propose Tool\", "+The propose tool is divided into two parts, and will automatically display the relevant one to you when you open the tool, depending on whether you run it from \the master\ (currently that is Castle Marrach) or from \a slave\ (every other server out there).", "+", "+To open the tool, type \+propose\ from the client command line.", "+\
From the master.\The tool will display the administer face when you run it from the master. From there, you can review pending proposals, apply them (thus enabling that piece of code) or discard them (thus removing that proposal from the open queue). Submitted entries remain on the server until they are 6 months old. Regardless whether they are open or closed, applied or discarded, entries are removed after this period. Thus,", "+\\
Applied code can be traced back to the submitter (and reviewer) in case of issues. Thus, ensure that when you review items, do so seriously. If you are asked to apply a proposal, decline the request as you should only review if you are competent enough to understand the submitted code in question.\\
Discarded code can be retrieved if it was discarded by mistake.\\
Closed entries can be referred to, applied and discarded alike, and possibly re-applied in case something goes wrong somewhere.\\
Open entries must be addressed in a timely (6 months isn't timely, but better late than never) manner or they run the risk of being purged from the system.\\\
\" \}), 1141303476, "zwoc" \})

(\{ (\{ "-\", "+\\", "=10", "-\\
=1\\
+ * D=Lookup a character \\\\\$name. If \\\\\$possessed is set, the functionality is identical to that of Lib:LPCompat/!determine_user.\\
+ *\\
+ * Author: Kalle Alm\\
+ * Since: 2002\\
+ */\\
+if (\\\\\$possessed) return Call(\\\\\$\{Lib:LPCompat\}, \\"!determine_user\\");\\
=1\\
- D=This function is now a simple wrapper for the SLib:common/lib:lookup function, which is the one to use.\\
+return Get(\\\\\$\{UserAPI:UDatD\}, \\"bodies:\\" + Str(\\\\\$name));\\
-\\
+/*\\
- Parameter is: \\\\\$name: \\\\*name*\\
+ * ChangeLog ![\\
-\\
+ * Change(2006-03-02; Zwoc)=Modified lookup to use central code rather than call SLib:common version.\\
- E.g. \\\\\$charobj = CallArg( \\\\\$\{Marrach:Merrylibs:commonlib\}, \\"lookup\\", \\\\\$name: \\"kalle\\" );\\
+ * ]\\
-\\
+ */\\
-*/\\
-\\
-return Call(\\\\\$\{SLib:common\}, \\"lookup\\");\\", "+\\
=1\\
+ * D=Lookup a character \\\\\$name. If \\\\\$possessed is set, the functionality is identical to that of Lib:LPCompat/!determine_user.\\
+ *\\
+ * Author: Kalle Alm\\
+ * Since: 2002\\
+ */\\
+if (\\\\\$possessed) return Call(\\\\\$\{Lib:LPCompat\}, \\"!determine_user\\");\\

+return Get(\\\\\$\{UserAPI:UDatD\}, \\"bodies:\\" + Str(\\\\\$name));\\
-\\
+/*\\
- Parameter is: \\\\\$name: \\\\*name*\\
+ * ChangeLog ![\\
-\\
+ * Change(2006-03-02; Zwoc)=Modified lookup to use central code rather than call SLib:common version.\\
- E.g. \\\\\$charobj = CallArg( \\\\\$\{Marrach:Merrylibs:commonlib\}, \\"lookup\\", \\\\\$name: \\"kalle\\" );\\
+ * ]\\
-\\
+ */\\
-*/\\
-\\
-return Call(\\\\\$\{SLib:common\}, \\"lookup\\");\\\
From a slave.\Slaves are the place where proposals are \made, \and the master is where proposals are \judged\. When you run \+propose\ from a slave, you will be prompted to supply Object, Property, and Destination Object.", "-\", "+The first is the object which you intend to submit. The second is the property in that object. The third is the destiniation object on the master. This separation allows you to, for instance, make a local copy of global code to prevent your changes to it from being oversynced and then submit \from\ that object.", "+", "+\
\" \}), 1141305277, "zwoc" \})

(\{ (\{ "=5", "-\\
Applied code can be traced back to the submitter (and reviewer) in case of issues. Thus, ensure that when you review items, do so seriously. If you are asked to apply a proposal, decline the request as you should only review if you are competent enough to understand the submitted code in question.\\
Discarded code can be retrieved if it was discarded by mistake.\\
Closed entries can be referred to, applied and discarded alike, and possibly re-applied in case something goes wrong somewhere.\\
Open entries must be addressed in a timely (6 months isn't timely, but better late than never) manner or they run the risk of being purged from the system.\\\
\", "+\\
Applied code can be traced back to the submitter (and reviewer) in case of issues. Thus, ensure that when you review items, do so seriously. If you are asked to apply a proposal, decline the request as you should only review if you are competent enough to understand the submitted code in question.\\
Discarded code can be retrieved if it was discarded by mistake.\\
Closed entries can be referred to, applied and discarded alike, and possibly re-applied in case something goes wrong somewhere.\\
Open entries must be addressed in a timely (6 months isn't timely, but better late than never) manner or they run the risk of being purged from the system.\\", "+When you review a proposal, you will see a diff report on the changes that will be made to the piece of code in question. Part from this diff, you will also see the new code in its entirety. The diff will only display \differences\ using three symbols:", "+\\
\Equal-sign (=)\ is used to express that a number of lines were \equal\ in the two versions of the code. The number of lines comes directly after the equals-sign; like so: \=5\ (5 lines were equal in A and B)\\
\Plus-sign (+)\ is used to express that a line was \added\ by the newer diff. \+EmitTo(\$actor, \\"Hello\\");\ (the line 'EmitTo(\$actor, \\"Hello\\");' was added to the code)\\
\Minus-sign (-)\ is used to express that a line was \removed\ from the old diff. \-/* This line is in the old version */\ (the line '/* This line is in the old version */' was removed from the code)\\Additionally, the three types are colorized in the diff output using \html::implode_diff\ to where = entries are grayish, + entries are greenish and - entries are reddish, to better describe what's going on.", "+", "+Thus, for instance, a diff report might look like this:", "+", "+\
\" \}), 1141303922, "zwoc" \})

"\\\ \
The Propose Tool\\The propose tool is divided into two parts, and will automatically display the relevant one to you when you open the tool, depending on whether you run it from \the master\ (currently that is Castle Marrach) or from \a slave\ (every other server out there).\\To open the tool, type \+propose\ from the client command line.\\
From the master.\The tool will display the administer face when you run it from the master. From there, you can review pending proposals, apply them (thus enabling that piece of code) or discard them (thus removing that proposal from the open queue). Submitted entries remain on the server until they are 6 months old. Regardless whether they are open or closed, applied or discarded, entries are removed after this period. Thus,\\\
Applied code can be traced back to the submitter (and reviewer) in case of issues. Thus, ensure that when you review items, do so seriously. If you are asked to apply a proposal, decline the request as you should only review if you are competent enough to understand the submitted code in question.\\
Discarded code can be retrieved if it was discarded by mistake.\\
Closed entries can be referred to, applied and discarded alike, and possibly re-applied in case something goes wrong somewhere.\\
Open entries must be addressed in a timely (6 months isn't timely, but better late than never) manner or they run the risk of being purged from the system.\\\When you review a proposal, you will see a diff report on the changes that will be made to the piece of code in question. Part from this diff, you will also see the new code in its entirety. The diff will only display \differences\ using three symbols:\\\
\Equal-sign (=)\ is used to express that a number of lines were \equal\ in the two versions of the code. The number of lines comes directly after the equals-sign; like so: \=5\ (5 lines were equal in A and B)\\
\Plus-sign (+)\ is used to express that a line was \added\ by the newer diff. \+EmitTo(\$actor, \\"Hello\\");\ (the line 'EmitTo(\$actor, \\"Hello\\");' was added to the code)\\
\Minus-sign (-)\ is used to express that a line was \removed\ from the old diff. \-/* This line is in the old version */\ (the line '/* This line is in the old version */' was removed from the code)\\Additionally, the three types are colorized in the diff output using \html::!implode_diff\ to where = entries are grayish, + entries are greenish and - entries are reddish, to better describe what's going on.\\Thus, for instance, a diff report might look like this:\\\
=1\\
+ * D=Lookup a character \\\\\$name. If \\\\\$possessed is set, the functionality is identical to that of Lib:LPCompat/!determine_user.\\
+ *\\
+ * Author: Kalle Alm\\
+ * Since: 2002\\
+ */\\
+if (\\\\\$possessed) return Call(\\\\\$\{Lib:LPCompat\}, \\"!determine_user\\");\\
=1\\
- D=This function is now a simple wrapper for the SLib:common/lib:lookup function, which is the one to use.\\
+return Get(\\\\\$\{UserAPI:UDatD\}, \\"bodies:\\" + Str(\\\\\$name));\\
-\\
+/*\\
- Parameter is: \\\\\$name: \\\\*name*\\
+ * ChangeLog ![\\
-\\
+ * Change(2006-03-02; Zwoc)=Modified lookup to use central code rather than call SLib:common version.\\
- E.g. \\\\\$charobj = CallArg( \\\\\$\{Marrach:Merrylibs:commonlib\}, \\"lookup\\", \\\\\$name: \\"kalle\\" );\\
+ * ]\\
-\\
+ */\\
-*/\\
-\\
-return Call(\\\\\$\{SLib:common\}, \\"lookup\\");\\\
From a slave.\Slaves are the place where proposals are \made, \and the master is where proposals are \judged\. When you run \+propose\ from a slave, you will be prompted to supply Object, Property, and Destination Object.\The first is the object which you intend to submit. The second is the property in that object. The third is the destiniation object on the master. This separation allows you to, for instance, make a local copy of global code to prevent your changes to it from being oversynced and then submit \from\ that object.\\\
\"
